history.content:
<md>> How important is 61c for upper division courses

This depends on the upper div. Lower-level courses like Computer Architecture (CS152) and Digital Design (EECS151) develop very directly off hardware and architecture concepts taught in 61C, and if you struggled in the datapath/pipelining sections of 61C you'll likely struggle in these classes as well. Systems courses (Embedded Systems [EECS149], Security [CS161], Operating Systems [CS162], Compilers [CS164], Databases [CS186]) are based heavily off the software concepts in 61C. In particular, CS162 goes a lot more in depth into how to handle concurrency/multithreading in big programs, and really requires you to understand C well. 161, 162, and 164 will all be easier if you're comfortable with programming in assembly language, though most of what you need can be relearned within those classes.

Mathy/algorithmy upper divs (126, 127, 170, 189, etc.) are pretty orthogonal to 61C.

> for ... SWE in general

The most important skills for SWE in 61C are probably being able to use a debugger (though languages that are higher-level than C probably have nice debuggers integrated into the IDE), manage large software projects, and reason about performance of your code. The first 2 can be honed with practice in other, non-C/asembly languages, but the last requires you to understand the underlying hardware characteristics to a certain extent. For example, you should have a basic understanding of how memory access patterns interact with the cache/virtual memory, and describe at a high level what's happening when multiple threads are running on one CPU. CS162 goes into these concepts in greater detail, and for that reason is often highly recommended for people who want to do SWE once they graduate.

> relearning material

This depends on what material you want to relearn -- for more abstract things, going over discussion problems (and old exam problems on the topic) could certainly be helpful. For concrete, coding-related things, you could try redoing class projects, but for stuff like data structure manipulations, leetcode problems might also be useful.

(source: ex-TA for 61C, have taken most of these classes)</md>

I'm struggling a lot in CS61c but will probably still pass the class (~ C range). How important is 61c for upper division courses and SWE in general? I'm wondering if I should spend winter break relearning the material, and if I do that, should I just redo discussions? Does anyone have any tips on how they did well/learned the content in 61c? thanks!
history.subject: don't understand cs61c
